thread.title: Rockefeller Preserve public-private land swap proposed
thread.title_full: Rockefeller Preserve public-private land swap proposed

title: Rockefeller Preserve public-private land swap proposed
text:
Rockefeller Preserve public-private land swap proposed Bill Cary , wcary@lohud.com 5:30 p.m. EDT October 5, 2015 Land swap would preserve open meadow along Route 448; hearing set for Wednesday. Buy Photo A proposed land swap would preserve an open meadow near the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture. (Photo: Mark Vergari, Staff TJN file photo) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The state is proposing a land swap to prevent a private landowner from building a new house in the middle of a scenic open meadow next to the Rockefeller State Park Preserve. 
The swap would give the Mount Pleasant landowner 6.856 acres from within the park's boundaries in exchange for a private parcel of the same size. 
A public hearing on the Draft Environmental Impact Statement for the land exchange will be held at 6:30 p.m. Wednesday at The Gallery at the Rockefeller Preserve, 125 Phelps Way, which is near the entrance to the 1,486-acre Mount Pleasant park. 
The hearing will be held by the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, the group proposing the land swap as a way to protect the valuable views of the park and surrounding land. The scenic meadow is in full view of the nearby Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture in Pocantico Hills and passing drivers on Route 448. 
The parcel that the private landowner would get in exchange is characterized by fairly young woodlands that would remain largely intact, after some clearing to make way for a new house, the state said. A proposed septic system on the site has already been approved, and there is another private home and private land next door. 
The 6.856-acre parcel that would be transferred to the state would remain as an open meadow, under the plan. 
The draft impact statement is available at: nysparks.com/inside-our-agency/master-plans.aspx . Copies are also available for review at the Warner Library serving Tarrytown and Sleepy Hollow, 121 N. Broadway, Tarrytown; Briarcliff Manor Public Library, 1 Library Road, Briarcliff Manor; and Mount Pleasant Public Library, 350 Bedford Road, Pleasantville. 
The public is invited to provide comments at the hearing or in writing through Oct. 22. All written comments should be forwarded to one of the following: By email to: Plan@parks.ny.gov Linda Cooper, AICP, Regional Director, Taconic State Park Region, PO Box 308, 9 Old Post Road, Staatsburg, NY 12580, Phone: (845) 889-4100 Ron Rausch, Director, Environmental Management Bureau, NYS Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, Albany, NY 12238, Phone: (518) 474-0409 1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://lohud.us/1LehaCt TOP VIDEOS
